admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, though sustainability is unlikely, given the
            Government of Turkey's lower than expected funding
            levels for longer term research, and the inability to retain
            income generated for the maintenance of staff (including a
            continued erosion of staff numbers, and technical capacity),
            particularly at the Agricultural Economics Research
            Institute (AERI). It is highlighted that despite lessons
            from previous sector operations, those were seemingly not
            incorporated into the project design, which would have
            helped in attaining sustainability, and enhanced
            institutional development. The first lesson points at the
            already known structural problems in the Ministry of
            Agriculture and Rural Affairs (MARA), namely that of a
            fragmented research structure, and inflexible personnel
            management policy, which were not addressed; thus, it is
            paramount for future operations to acknowledge the risks of
            proceeding with investment lending, in the absence of
            broader structural, and civil service reforms. Moreover, the
            insufficient local ownership within the research community,
            or MARA, calls for broader stakeholder involvement, and
            commitment to project design during preparation of future
            operations. And, while the research funding through a
            competitive grant system worked reasonably well, such grants
            need to be complemented by funding for longer-term research,
            carefully explained to the research, and extension
            community, with particular attention to procurement, and
            financial arrangements, as well as commitments to long term
            technical assistance.
